q: Who founded the Indian National Congress in 1885?
desc: AO Hume, a retired British civil servant, founded the Indian National Congress in 1885.

q: Where was the first session of the Indian National Congress held?
desc: The first INC session was held in Bombay in 1885.

q: Who presided over the first session of the Indian National Congress?
desc: W.C. Bannerjee was the president of the first INC session in 1885.

q: How many delegates attended the first session of INC in 1885?
desc: 72 delegates from all over India attended the first session of the INC.

q: Which of the following best describes the first two decades of the INC?
desc: The early INC was dominated by moderate leaders with faith in British justice.

q: Which leader is NOT considered a moderate?
desc: Lala Lajpat Rai was part of the extremist faction, unlike the early moderates.

q: Who announced the Partition of Bengal?
desc: Lord Curzon announced the partition of Bengal in 1905.

q: When was the Partition of Bengal officially announced?
desc: The Partition of Bengal was officially announced on 16th October 1905.

q: What new region was created from Bengal during the 1905 partition?
desc: East Bengal and Assam were created by partitioning the old Bengal province.

q: What movement originated from the anti-partition movement of Bengal?
desc: The Swadeshi Movement emerged in response to the partition of Bengal.

q: Which leaders were prominently associated with the Swadeshi Movement?
desc: Lala Lajpat Rai, Bal Gangadhar Tilak, Bipin Chandra Pal, and Aurobindo Ghosh led the Swadeshi Movement.

q: Which INC session first adopted the Swadeshi call?
desc: The Banaras Session of INC in 1905, presided by GK Gokhale, adopted the Swadeshi call.

q: Who presided over the INC Banaras Session of 1905?
desc: Gopal Krishna Gokhale presided over the Banaras Session of the INC in 1905.

q: When was the Muslim League formed?
desc: The All-India Muslim League was formed in 1906.

q: Who was *not* among the founders of the Muslim League?
desc: Gopal Krishna Gokhale was a moderate leader of the INC, not a founder of the Muslim League.

q: What was one of the key demands of the Muslim League?
desc: The Muslim League demanded special safeguards for Muslims, including a separate electorate.

q: Which movement did the Muslim League oppose?
desc: The Muslim League opposed the Swadeshi Movement, which was tied to Hindu nationalist sentiment.

q: What was the Muslim League's stance on the Partition of Bengal?
desc: The Muslim League supported the Partition of Bengal, unlike the INC.

q: Which of the following INC leaders was a key moderate voice?
desc: Dadabhai Naoroji was one of the foremost moderate leaders of the Indian National Congress.

q: Which of these sessions was associated with the Swadeshi call?
desc: The Swadeshi movement was officially adopted at the Banaras Session of the INC in 1905.

q: In which session did the INC adopt 'Swaraj' as its goal?
desc: The Calcutta Session of 1906, under Dadabhai Naoroji, adopted Swaraj as the goal.

q: Who led the INC during the Calcutta Session of 1906?
desc: Dadabhai Naoroji was the leader of INC during the 1906 Calcutta Session.

q: What does the term 'Swaraj' mean?
desc: 'Swaraj' translates to self-government and was the INC’s goal in 1906.

q: At which session did the INC split into Moderates and Extremists?
desc: The Surat Session of 1907 saw the split between Moderates and Extremists in the INC.

q: Who were the leaders of the Extremist faction during the INC split?
desc: The Extremists were led by Lala Lajpat Rai, Bal Gangadhar Tilak, and Bipin Chandra Pal.

q: Who led the Moderates during the Surat Session split?
desc: Gopal Krishna Gokhale led the Moderates during the 1907 INC split at Surat.

q: What was the main reason for the split at the Surat Session?
desc: The nature and direction of the Swadeshi Movement caused the rift at Surat.

q: Which reforms introduced a separate electorate for Muslims?
desc: The 1909 Morley-Minto Reforms introduced separate electorates for Muslims.

q: In which year were the Morley-Minto Reforms passed?
desc: The reforms were enacted in 1909 to increase Indian participation in governance.

q: Which British official is known as the 'Father of Communal Electorate'?
desc: Lord Minto was called the Father of Communal Electorate for supporting separate electorates.

q: Where was the Ghadar Party headquartered?
desc: The Ghadar Party was headquartered in San Francisco, USA.

q: Who was NOT a founder of the Ghadar Party?
desc: Tilak was not associated with Ghadar Party; it was founded by Hardayal, Das, and Bhakna.

q: When was the Ghadar newspaper first published?
desc: The first issue of the Ghadar newspaper was published on 1st November 1913.

q: What historical event did the Ghadar newspaper commemorate?
desc: The Ghadar paper was launched to honor the spirit of the 1857 Revolt.

q: When did Tilak launch the Home Rule Movement?
desc: Tilak launched the Home Rule Movement in April 1916 at Poona.

q: Where did Tilak start his Home Rule League?
desc: Tilak's Home Rule League was based in Poona.

q: Who co-founded the Home Rule Movement along with Tilak?
desc: Annie Besant, along with Tilak, led the Home Rule Movement.

q: Where was Annie Besant’s Home Rule League headquartered?
desc: Annie Besant's Home Rule League operated from Adyar, near Madras.

q: Who raised the slogan 'Swaraj is my birth right and I shall have it'?
desc: Tilak gave this iconic slogan during the Home Rule Movement.

q: What was the aim of the Home Rule Movement?
desc: The movement aimed at achieving self-rule within the British Empire.

q: Which two parties came together in the Lucknow Pact of 1916?
desc: The Lucknow Pact was a collaboration between the INC and Muslim League.

q: Which global event influenced the Lucknow Pact?
desc: World War I and British-Turkish conflict led to Muslim distrust and the pact.

q: What status did both INC and Muslim League demand in the Lucknow Pact?
desc: Both parties demanded dominion status for India in the Lucknow Pact.

q: Which key concession did INC give in the Lucknow Pact?
desc: INC agreed to separate electorates for Muslims in the Lucknow Pact.

q: Who was the first president of the Muslim League?
desc: Aga Khan was the first president of the Muslim League formed in 1906.

q: Which year marked the Lucknow Pact?
desc: The INC and Muslim League agreed upon the Lucknow Pact in 1916.

q: Who among the following was NOT a Home Rule Movement leader?
desc: Gandhi was not directly involved in the Home Rule Movement.

q: Which movement introduced political awakening in Indian diaspora abroad?
desc: The Ghadar Movement united Indians abroad for India's freedom.

q: What was the purpose of the August Declaration of 1917?
pool: To grant full independence to India
To increase Indian participation in administration
answer: To increase Indian participation in administration
desc: The August Declaration aimed at progressively increasing Indian involvement in governance.

q: Which reforms were based on the August Declaration?
desc: The 1919 Montague-Chelmsford Reforms were framed based on the August Declaration.

q: In which year was the August Declaration announced?
desc: The British announced the August Declaration in 1917.

q: What did the Rowlatt Act of 1919 allow the British government to do?
desc: The Rowlatt Act allowed arrest and imprisonment without trial, sparking major protests.

q: Which civil right was suspended under the Rowlatt Act?
desc: The Rowlatt Act suspended Habeas Corpus, a fundamental legal protection.

q: Which movement was launched by Gandhiji in response to the Rowlatt Act?
desc: Gandhiji launched the Rowlatt Satyagraha in 1919 as a nationwide protest.

q: What was significant about the Rowlatt Satyagraha?
pool: It was the first all-India agitation by Gandhiji
answer: It was the first all-India agitation by Gandhiji
desc: Rowlatt Satyagraha marked Gandhiji’s first countrywide political movement.

q: When did the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre occur?
desc: The massacre took place on 13th April 1919 in Amritsar.

q: Who was responsible for the Jallianwala Bagh firing?
desc: General Dyer ordered open fire on the crowd in Jallianwala Bagh.

q: Who was the Lt. Governor of Punjab during the Jallianwala Bagh massacre?
desc: Michael O'Dwyer was the Lt. Governor of Punjab during the massacre.

q: Which two leaders' arrest led to the protest in Jallianwala Bagh?
pool: Dr Saifuddin Kitchlew and Dr Satya Pal
answer: Dr Saifuddin Kitchlew and Dr Satya Pal
desc: The arrest of these two leaders triggered the gathering at Jallianwala Bagh.

q: Which commission was appointed to investigate the Jallianwala Bagh massacre?
desc: The British appointed the Hunter Commission to investigate the incident.

q: Who returned his knighthood in protest of the Jallianwala Bagh massacre?
desc: Rabindranath Tagore renounced his knighthood as a mark of protest.

q: Who assassinated Michael O'Dwyer in 1940?
desc: Sardar Udham Singh assassinated Michael O'Dwyer in London in 1940.

q: Where was Michael O'Dwyer killed?
desc: Udham Singh killed O'Dwyer at Caxton Hall in London.

q: Why were Indian Muslims upset after World War I?
pool: Treatment of Turkey by the British
answer: Treatment of Turkey by the British
desc: The harsh treatment of Turkey post-WWI hurt Muslim sentiments in India.

q: Who led the Khilafat Movement?
desc: The Khilafat Movement was led by Mohd Ali and Shaukat Ali.

q: Which movement was jointly led by the Khilafat leaders and the Congress?
desc: The Khilafat Movement was jointly led with the Congress to support the Caliph.

q: In which year was the Non-Cooperation Movement launched?
desc: The Non-Cooperation Movement began in 1920 following the Khilafat and Jallianwala incidents.

q: At which session was the Non-Cooperation resolution passed?
desc: The Calcutta Session in 1920 passed the Non-Cooperation resolution.

q: Which was the first mass political movement led by Gandhiji?
desc: The Non-Cooperation Movement was Gandhi’s first mass political initiative.

q: Which of the following was NOT part of the Non-Cooperation programme?
desc: The movement called for non-participation in British institutions, including elections.

q: Which professions were particularly asked to boycott under Non-Cooperation?
desc: Lawyers were encouraged to boycott British courts under this movement.

q: What was the public’s expected action toward military recruitment under the movement?
desc: Gandhiji called on people to refuse recruitment in British forces.

q: What kind of goods did the Non-Cooperation Movement promote boycotting?
desc: The movement urged people to boycott all foreign-manufactured goods.

q: Which treaty post-WWI triggered the Khilafat Movement?
desc: The Treaty of Sèvres diminished Turkish sovereignty, prompting the Khilafat Movement.

q: Which movement marks the beginning of mass politics under Gandhiji’s leadership?
desc: It was Gandhiji’s first large-scale political movement mobilizing masses.

q: What incident led Gandhiji to withdraw the Non-Cooperation Movement?
desc: The violent Chauri-Chaura incident on 5th February 1922 led Gandhiji to suspend the Non-Cooperation Movement.

q: When did the Chauri-Chaura incident take place?
desc: The Chauri-Chaura incident occurred on 5th February 1922.

q: Where did the Chauri-Chaura incident occur?
desc: Chauri-Chaura is located near Gorakhpur in Uttar Pradesh.

q: How many policemen were killed in the Chauri-Chaura incident?
desc: A mob set fire to a police station, killing 22 policemen during the incident.

q: On which date did Gandhiji withdraw the Non-Cooperation Movement?
desc: The movement was officially withdrawn by Gandhiji on 12th February 1922.

q: Who were called 'Pro-changers' in the Indian freedom movement?
pool: Those who wanted to end council boycott
answer: Those who wanted to end council boycott
desc: Pro-changers supported entering legislative councils to fight the British from within.

q: Who among the following was NOT a founding member of the Swaraj Party?
desc: Sardar Patel was not associated with the Swaraj Party at its formation.

q: Who became the first President of the Swaraj Party?
desc: C.R. Das served as the first president of the Swaraj Party.

q: What was the purpose of the Swaraj Party formed in 1923?
pool: To protest against Partition of Bengal
desc: The Swaraj Party aimed to expose British rule from within the councils.

q: What was the Simon Commission formed to review?
desc: Simon Commission was established to assess Indian governance and suggest reforms.

q: Why was the Simon Commission opposed by Indians?
desc: The Commission was boycotted because it had no Indian representatives.

q: What was the popular slogan raised against the Simon Commission?
desc: Protesters chanted 'Simon Go Back' across the country.

q: Who was severely injured during a Simon Commission protest in Lahore?
desc: Lala Lajpat Rai was brutally lathi-charged and later died of his injuries.

q: Who chaired the committee that drafted the Nehru Report?
desc: The Nehru Report was prepared under the chairmanship of Motilal Nehru.

q: Why was the Nehru Report prepared?
pool: To present a constitution for India
answer: To present a constitution for India
desc: The report aimed to define constitutional principles for a free India.

q: In which year was the Nehru Report published?
desc: The Nehru Report was formulated and submitted in 1928.

q: When was Poorna Swaraj declared as the goal of the Congress?
desc: Poorna Swaraj was declared at the Lahore Session of the INC in 1929.

q: Who was the President of the INC during the Lahore Session of 1929?
desc: Jawaharlal Nehru presided over the 1929 Lahore Session.

q: What was the significance of 26th January 1930?
desc: Congress observed 26th January 1930 as India’s first Independence Day.

q: Which flag was adopted during the Lahore Session of 1929?
desc: The Indian National Congress adopted the tri-colour flag on 31st December 1929.

q: On which date was the tri-colour flag unfurled by the Congress in 1929?
desc: The tri-colour was officially unfurled by INC on the night of 31st December 1929.

q: Why was 26th January later chosen as the Republic Day of India?
pool: It marked end of British rule
It was the date of Poorna Swaraj celebration
It was when Constitution was adopted
It was the date of Dandi March
answer: It was the date of Poorna Swaraj celebration
desc: 26th January commemorated the original declaration of Poorna Swaraj.

q: What did the Lahore Session of Congress in 1929 declare as its ultimate goal?
desc: The Lahore Session of 1929 declared complete independence as the goal.

q: Which session of INC declared 26th January as Independence Day?
desc: INC at its Lahore Session under Jawaharlal Nehru fixed 26th Jan 1930 for celebrating Independence Day.

q: What was the Dandi March also known as?
desc: The Dandi March was popularly known as the Salt Satyagraha.

q: When did Gandhiji start the Dandi March?
desc: Gandhiji began the historic Dandi March on 12th March 1930 from Sabarmati Ashram.

q: From which place did Gandhiji begin the Dandi March?
desc: The march began from Sabarmati Ashram, located near Ahmedabad.

q: What was the main purpose of the Dandi March?
desc: Gandhiji launched the march to break the British monopoly on salt.

q: What symbolic act did Gandhiji perform at Dandi?
desc: He picked a handful of salt to mark the beginning of Civil Disobedience Movement.

q: What major movement was inaugurated by the Dandi March?
desc: The Civil Disobedience Movement began with the Salt Satyagraha at Dandi.

q: Which group showed unprecedented participation in the Civil Disobedience Movement?
desc: Women participated in large numbers in the Civil Disobedience Movement.

q: Which soldiers refused to fire on people at Peshawar during the movement?
desc: Garhwal soldiers showed defiance by refusing to shoot protestors in Peshawar.

q: When was the First Round Table Conference held?
desc: The First Round Table Conference was held in London in 1930.

q: Where was the First Round Table Conference held?
desc: It was held in London starting from 12th November 1930.

q: What was the main topic of discussion in the First Round Table Conference?
desc: The conference was convened to discuss the findings of the Simon Commission.

q: Which major Indian political party did NOT attend the First Round Table Conference?
desc: The Congress boycotted the First Round Table Conference, leading to its failure.

q: Which pact marked the end of the first phase of the Civil Disobedience Movement?
desc: The Gandhi-Irwin Pact led to the suspension of the Civil Disobedience Movement.

q: When was the Gandhi-Irwin Pact signed?
desc: The pact was signed between Gandhiji and Lord Irwin on 5th March 1931.

q: Who represented the British government in the Gandhi-Irwin Pact?
desc: Lord Irwin, the Viceroy of India, represented the British in the agreement.

q: What did the INC agree to under the Gandhi-Irwin Pact?
desc: INC agreed to join the Second Round Table Conference after the pact.

q: What concession did the British give regarding the Salt Law in the Gandhi-Irwin Pact?
desc: Villagers were allowed to make salt for personal use under the pact.

q: Which session of Congress endorsed the Gandhi-Irwin Pact?
desc: The 1931 Karachi Session of Congress approved the Gandhi-Irwin Pact.

q: What was one result of the Gandhi-Irwin Pact related to prisoners?
desc: The pact led to the release of political prisoners not charged with violence.

q: Which movement followed immediately after the Dandi March?
desc: The Civil Disobedience Movement was launched with the Salt Satyagraha.

q: What was the INC's stance on the First Round Table Conference?
desc: The Indian National Congress boycotted the First Round Table Conference.

q: Which two parties participated in the First Round Table Conference?
desc: These two organizations took part in the conference despite INC’s absence.

q: Which act of defiance marked the beginning of the Salt Satyagraha?
desc: Gandhiji picked up salt from the shore at Dandi to launch the movement.

q: What was the main goal of the Salt Satyagraha?
desc: The movement aimed to oppose the unjust British salt monopoly and tax.

q: Which year saw the signing of the Gandhi-Irwin Pact?
desc: The Gandhi-Irwin Pact was concluded in the year 1931.

q: Who represented the Indian National Congress in the Second Round Table Conference?
desc: Mahatma Gandhi represented the INC in the Second Round Table Conference held in London.

q: Who was the British Prime Minister during the Second Round Table Conference?
desc: Ramsay McDonald was the British Prime Minister during the 1931 conference.

q: Why did the Second Round Table Conference fail?
desc: Gandhiji and Ramsay McDonald disagreed on communal representation and British refusal of freedom.

q: What was the Communal Award?
desc: The Communal Award announced communal representation for Muslims, Sikhs, and depressed classes.

q: Who announced the Communal Award in 1932?
desc: Ramsay McDonald announced the Communal Award on 16th August 1932.

q: What policy did the Communal Award reflect?
desc: The Award was criticized for promoting the British policy of divide and rule.

q: Which communities were given separate representation in the Communal Award?
desc: The Award proposed separate electorates for Muslims, Sikhs, and the depressed classes.

q: Where did Gandhiji start his fast unto death in 1932?
desc: Gandhiji protested the Communal Award by fasting in Yervada Jail, Pune.

q: What was the result of Gandhiji’s fast unto death?
desc: To end his fast, Gandhiji and Ambedkar signed the Poona Pact.

q: What was agreed upon in the Poona Pact?
desc: The depressed classes got increased reserved seats, but in a joint electorate with other castes.

q: Who were the key signatories of the Poona Pact?
desc: The pact was signed between Mahatma Gandhi and Dr. B.R. Ambedkar.

q: When was the Poona Pact signed?
desc: The Poona Pact was signed on 25th September 1932 to resolve the separate electorate issue.

q: Why did the Third Round Table Conference prove fruitless?
pool: Most national leaders were in prison
answer: Most national leaders were in prison
desc: The conference failed due to the absence of key Indian leaders who were jailed.

q: Who suggested the idea of Pakistan in 1930?
desc: In 1930, Allama Iqbal proposed creating Muslim states in north-western India.

q: What regions did Iqbal suggest for forming Muslim states in 1930?
desc: Iqbal proposed that the North-West provinces and Kashmir be made Muslim states within a federation.

q: When was the Pakistan Resolution passed by the Muslim League?
desc: The Muslim League passed the Pakistan Resolution in its Lahore Session in 1940.

q: Who moved the Pakistan Resolution in 1940?
desc: Fazlul Haq moved the Pakistan Resolution at the Lahore Session of the Muslim League in 1940.

q: Who drafted the Pakistan Resolution?
desc: Sikandar Hayat Khan drafted the Pakistan Resolution passed in 1940.

q: Who seconded the Pakistan Resolution?
desc: Khaliquzzamah seconded the Pakistan Resolution in 1940.

q: What slogan did the Muslim League adopt in its Karachi Session in 1943?
desc: In December 1943, the Muslim League adopted the slogan 'Divide and Quit' at its Karachi Session.

q: When was the August Offer made?
desc: The August Offer was made on 8th August 1940 by the British Government.

q: Which of these was NOT a part of the August Offer?
desc: The August Offer did not promise immediate independence but dominion status in the unspecified future.

q: Which political party rejected the August Offer?
desc: The Indian National Congress rejected the August Offer of 1940.

q: Who accepted the August Offer?
desc: The Muslim League accepted the August Offer of 1940.

q: Who was sent by the British Government in 1942 as part of a mission?
desc: Sir Stafford Cripps was sent to India in 1942 by the British to gain Indian cooperation during WWII.

q: What did Cripps offer to India in 1942?
desc: The Cripps Mission proposed dominion status to India after World War II.

q: How did Gandhiji describe the Cripps Mission offer?
pool: A post-dated cheque on a crashing bank
answer: A post-dated cheque on a crashing bank
desc: Gandhi called the Cripps offer 'a post-dated cheque on a crashing bank'.

q: What was another name for the Quit India Movement?
desc: The Quit India Movement was also known as the Wardha Proposal.

q: When was the Quit India Resolution passed?
desc: The Quit India Resolution was passed on 8th August 1942 at Bombay.

q: What slogan did Gandhiji give during the Quit India Movement?
desc: Gandhiji gave the slogan 'Do or Die' during the Quit India Movement.

q: Where was Gandhiji kept after his arrest in 1942?
desc: Gandhiji was detained at the Aga Khan Palace in Pune after his arrest during the Quit India Movement.

q: Which party was banned on 9th August 1942?
desc: The Indian National Congress was banned by the British Government on 9th August 1942.

q: How was the Quit India Movement described?
desc: The Quit India Movement was often termed a 'Leaderless Revolt' as most leaders were arrested early.

q: Which event directly preceded the Quit India Movement?
desc: The failure of the Cripps Mission led to the launch of the Quit India Movement in 1942.

q: What happened to the Quit India Movement eventually?
pool: It was crushed by the government
answer: It was crushed by the government
desc: The Quit India Movement was eventually suppressed by the British Government using military force.

q: Where did Subhash Chandra Bose set up the Indian League after escaping in 1941?
desc: After escaping from India in 1941, Subhash Chandra Bose set up the Indian League in Berlin.

q: In which year did Subhash Chandra Bose join the INA in Singapore?
desc: Subhash Chandra Bose joined the Indian National Army (INA) in July 1943 at Singapore.

q: Who handed over the leadership of the INA to Subhash Chandra Bose?
desc: Ras Bihari Bose handed over the leadership of the Indian National Army (INA) to Subhash Chandra Bose.

q: How many fighting brigades were there in the INA?
desc: The INA had three main fighting brigades named after Gandhi, Azad, and Nehru.

q: What was the name of the exclusive women's force in the INA?
desc: The Rani of Jhansi Brigade was the women's wing of the INA, composed exclusively of women fighters.

q: Where were the headquarters of the INA located?
desc: The Indian National Army had its headquarters in Singapore and Rangoon.

q: Which British leaders were part of the Cabinet Mission Plan of 1946?
desc: The Cabinet Mission of 1946 included Pethick Lawrence, Stafford Cripps, and A.V. Alexander.

q: Who was the Viceroy of India during the Cabinet Mission Plan?
desc: Lord Wavell was the Viceroy of India when the Cabinet Mission visited in 1946.

q: Which demand was rejected by the Cabinet Mission Plan?
desc: The Cabinet Mission Plan rejected the Muslim League's demand for a full-fledged Pakistan.

q: When did the Muslim League accept the Cabinet Mission Plan?
desc: The Muslim League accepted the Cabinet Mission Plan on 6th June 1946.
